trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics (Java) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics (Java) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Code samples are written for Java applications.
trans-unit.target: Code samples are written for Java applications.

trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics/subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics/subscriptions

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use Service Bus topics and
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use Service Bus topics and

trans-unit.source: subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Java and use the [Azure SDK for Java][].
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Java and use the [Azure SDK for Java][].

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include **creating topics and subscriptions**, **creating subscription filters**, **sending messages to a topic**, **receiving messages from a subscription**, and
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include **creating topics and subscriptions**, **creating subscription filters**, **sending messages to a topic**, **receiving messages from a subscription**, and

trans-unit.source: **deleting topics and subscriptions**.
trans-unit.target: **deleting topics and subscriptions**.

trans-unit.source: Configure your application to use Service Bus
trans-unit.target: Configure your application to use Service Bus

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have installed the [Azure SDK for Java][] before building this sample.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have installed the [Azure SDK for Java][] before building this sample.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Eclipse, you can install the [Azure Toolkit for Eclipse][] that includes the Azure SDK for Java.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Eclipse, you can install the [Azure Toolkit for Eclipse][] that includes the Azure SDK for Java.

trans-unit.source: You can then add the **Microsoft Azure Libraries for Java** to your project:
trans-unit.target: You can then add the **Microsoft Azure Libraries for Java** to your project:

trans-unit.source: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file:

trans-unit.source: Add the Azure Libraries for Java to your build path and include it in your project deployment assembly.
trans-unit.target: Add the Azure Libraries for Java to your build path and include it in your project deployment assembly.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that

trans-unit.source: restricts the set of messages passed to the subscription's virtual
trans-unit.target: restricts the set of messages passed to the subscription's virtual

trans-unit.source: queue.
trans-unit.target: queue.

trans-unit.source: Create a subscription with the default (MatchAll) filter
trans-unit.target: Create a subscription with the default (MatchAll) filter

trans-unit.source: The **MatchAll** filter is the default filter that is used if no filter
trans-unit.target: The **MatchAll** filter is the default filter that is used if no filter

trans-unit.source: is specified when a new subscription is created.
trans-unit.target: is specified when a new subscription is created.

trans-unit.source: When the **MatchAll**
trans-unit.target: When the **MatchAll**

trans-unit.source: filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the
trans-unit.target: filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the

trans-unit.source: subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.target: **BrokeredMessage** objects have a set of

trans-unit.target: standard methods (such as **setLabel** and **TimeToLive**), a dictionary

trans-unit.target: that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body

trans-unit.target: of arbitrary application data.

trans-unit.target: An application can set the body of the

trans-unit.target: message by passing any serializable object into the constructor of the

trans-unit.target: **BrokeredMessage**, and the appropriate **DataContractSerializer** will

trans-unit.target: then be used to serialize the object.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header,
trans-unit.target: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header,

trans-unit.source: which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have
trans-unit.target: which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have

trans-unit.source: a maximum size of 64 MB).
trans-unit.target: a maximum size of 64 MB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages

trans-unit.source: held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages
trans-unit.target: held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages

trans-unit.source: held by a topic.
trans-unit.target: held by a topic.

trans-unit.source: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an
trans-unit.target: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an

trans-unit.source: upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: How to receive messages from a subscription
trans-unit.target: How to receive messages from a subscription

trans-unit.source: The primary way to receive messages from a subscription is to use a
trans-unit.target: The primary way to receive messages from a subscription is to use a

trans-unit.source: **ServiceBusContract** object.
trans-unit.target: **ServiceBusContract** object.

trans-unit.source: Received messages can work in two
trans-unit.target: Received messages can work in two

trans-unit.source: different modes: **ReceiveAndDelete** and **PeekLock**.
trans-unit.target: different modes: **ReceiveAndDelete** and **PeekLock**.

trans-unit.source: When using the **ReceiveAndDelete** mode, receive is a single-shot
trans-unit.target: When using the **ReceiveAndDelete** mode, receive is a single-shot

trans-unit.source: operation - that is, when Service Bus receives a read request for a
trans-unit.target: operation - that is, when Service Bus receives a read request for a

trans-unit.source: message, it marks the message as being consumed and returns it to the
trans-unit.target: message, it marks the message as being consumed and returns it to the

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: **ReceiveAndDelete** mode is the simplest model and works
trans-unit.target: **ReceiveAndDelete** mode is the simplest model and works

trans-unit.source: best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a
trans-unit.target: best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a

trans-unit.source: message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a

trans-unit.source: scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then
trans-unit.target: scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then

trans-unit.source: crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the

trans-unit.source: message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins
trans-unit.target: message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins

trans-unit.source: consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was
trans-unit.target: consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was

trans-unit.source: consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: In **PeekLock** mode, receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes
trans-unit.target: In **PeekLock** mode, receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes

trans-unit.source: it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing
trans-unit.target: it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing

trans-unit.source: messages.
trans-unit.target: messages.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message

trans-unit.source: to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and
trans-unit.target: to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and

trans-unit.source: then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes

trans-unit.source: processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it
trans-unit.target: processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it

trans-unit.source: completes the second stage of the receive process by calling **Delete**
trans-unit.target: completes the second stage of the receive process by calling **Delete**

trans-unit.source: on the received message.
trans-unit.target: on the received message.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus sees the **Delete** call, it
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus sees the **Delete** call, it

trans-unit.source: will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the topic.
trans-unit.target: will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the topic.

trans-unit.source: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and
trans-unit.target: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and

trans-unit.source: processed using **PeekLock** mode (not the default mode).
trans-unit.target: processed using **PeekLock** mode (not the default mode).

trans-unit.source: The example
trans-unit.target: The example

trans-unit.source: below performs a loop and processes messages in the "HighMessages" subscription and then exits when there are no more messages (alternatively, it could be set to wait for new messages).

trans-unit.source: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages
trans-unit.target: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from

trans-unit.source: errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a
trans-unit.target: If a

trans-unit.source: receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason,
trans-unit.target: receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason,

trans-unit.source: then it can call the **unlockMessage** method on the received message
trans-unit.target: then it can call the **unlockMessage** method on the received message

trans-unit.source: (instead of the **deleteMessage** method).
trans-unit.target: (instead of the **deleteMessage** method).

trans-unit.source: This will cause Service Bus
trans-unit.target: This will cause Service Bus

trans-unit.source: to unlock the message within the topic and make it available to be
trans-unit.target: to unlock the message within the topic and make it available to be

trans-unit.source: received again, either by the same consuming application or by another
trans-unit.target: received again, either by the same consuming application or by another

trans-unit.source: consuming application.
trans-unit.target: consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the

trans-unit.source: topic, and if the application fails to process the message before the
trans-unit.target: topic, and if the application fails to process the message before the

trans-unit.source: lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service
trans-unit.target: lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service

trans-unit.source: Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be
trans-unit.target: Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be

trans-unit.source: received again.
trans-unit.target: received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message

trans-unit.source: but before the **deleteMessage** request is issued, then the message
trans-unit.target: but before the **deleteMessage** request is issued, then the message

trans-unit.source: will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often
trans-unit.target: This is often

trans-unit.source: called **At Least Once Processing**, that is, each message will be
trans-unit.target: called **At Least Once Processing**, that is, each message will be

trans-unit.source: processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may
trans-unit.target: processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may

trans-unit.source: be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing,
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing,

trans-unit.source: then application developers should add additional logic to their
trans-unit.target: then application developers should add additional logic to their

trans-unit.source: application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved

trans-unit.source: using the **getMessageId** method of the message, which will remain
trans-unit.target: using the **getMessageId** method of the message, which will remain

trans-unit.source: constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.source: How to delete topics and subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to delete topics and subscriptions

trans-unit.source: The primary way to delete topics and subscriptions is to use a
trans-unit.target: The primary way to delete topics and subscriptions is to use a

trans-unit.source: **ServiceBusContract** object.
trans-unit.target: **ServiceBusContract** object.

trans-unit.source: Deleting a topic will also delete any subscriptions that are registered
trans-unit.target: Deleting a topic will also delete any subscriptions that are registered

trans-unit.source: with the topic.
trans-unit.target: with the topic.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.
